case_name: M/s. Tiffins Barytes, Asbestos and Paints Ltd. v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2596 and 2597 of 1966 are appeals by special leave from orders dated May 2, 1966 and June 22, 1966 of the Government of India

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2596 and 2597 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the Orders dated May 2, 1966 and June 22, 1966 of the Government of India, Ministry of Mines and Metals, New Delhi on application is filed by the appellant under Rule 54 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1960.

facts.text: Appellant filed applications for mining lease for asbestos over Ac.1 13-50 in Brahmanapalli village and Ac. 13-10 in Ippatta village, Cuddapah District

anchor.surface_text: the appellant submitted two applications in the prescribed form viz., Form I for areas aggregating Ac. 113-50 in village Brahmanapalli and Ac. 13-10 in village Ippatta both in the district of Cuddapah for mining asbestos.

facts.text: Notification dated January 8, 1964 published in the State Gazette by Andhra Pradesh Government inviting applications under r. 58 of the rules

anchor.surface_text: In response to a notification dated January 8, 1964 published in the State Gazette by the Andhra Pradesh Government inviting applications under r. 58 of the rules framed under the Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, 1957

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 made similar applications on the same date as appellant

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 also made similar applications on the same date.

facts.text: Appellant claimed his applications complied with all requirements of Form I while those of respondent No. 3 were defective

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant his applications complied with all the requirements of Form I while those of respondent No. 3 were defective in some respects.

facts.text: Government of Andhra Pradesh preferred respondent No. 3 over appellant by order dated 19th October 1964

anchor.surface_text: As between the other applicants Sri Bhagat Raja and M s. Tiffins Barytes, Asbestos and, Paints Ltd., the Government prefer M s. Tiffins Barytes as they are having adequate general experience and technical knowledge

facts.text: State Government preferred respondent No. 3 because they have adequate general experience, technical knowledge, old lessees in district without arrears

anchor.surface_text: the Government prefer M s. Tiffins Barytes as they are having adequate general experience and technical knowledge, and are old lessees in the district, without any arrears of mineral dues to the Government.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision applications to Union of India on December 14, 1964 under s.30 Act r.54 in Form N

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed application in revision in the prescribed form i.e. Form N under s. 30 of the Act read with r. 54 to the Union of India on December 14, 1964.

facts.text: 3rd respondent filed counter statement to revision in April 1965

anchor.surface_text: The 3rd respondent filed a counter statement to the revision application in April 1965.

facts.text: Appellant filed rejoinder to 3rd respondent's counter in May 1965

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed rejoinder to the counter statements of the 3rd respondent in May 1965

facts.text: Appellant received comments of Andhra Pradesh Government in March 1966

anchor.surface_text: In March 1966 the appellant received the comments of the Andhra Pradesh Government on his revision applications.

facts.text: Appellant filed rejoinder to State comments in April 1966

anchor.surface_text: and to the comments of the Andhra Pradesh Government in April 1966.

facts.text: Appellant asked for personal hearing before decision, which was not given

anchor.surface_text: He also asked for the grant of a personal hearing before the decision of the case which was not given.

facts.text: Central Government rejected revision applications by orders dated June 22, 1966

anchor.surface_text: New Delhi, the 22nd June, 1966. I am directed to refer to your revision application dated 14-12-1964 and letter dated 28-1-1966 on the above subject and to say that after careful consideration of the grounds stated therein, the Central Government have come to the conclusion that there is no valid ground for interfering with the decision of the Government of Andhra Pradesh rejecting your application for grant of mining lease for asbestos over an area of Ac.1 13-50 in Brahmanapalli village, Cuddapah District, Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: Appellant claimed respondent No. 3 had no experience in asbestos mining, unsatisfactory financial position, application not in proper form

anchor.surface_text: Various grounds of appeal were taken in the application for special leave to appeal preferred by the appellant. An attempt has been made therein to show that respondent No. 3 had no experience in asbestos mining, that its financial position was very unsatisfactory and that its application for mining lease was not in proper form.

facts.text: Appeals limited to question whether Union of India bound to make speaking order in dismissing revision

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave, are limited to the question as to whether in dismissing a revision and confirming the order of the State of Andhra Pradesh, the Union of India was bound to make a speaking order.

facts.text: Court not called upon to go into merits of the case

anchor.surface_text: We are not called upon in this case to go into the merits of the case but only to examine the question as to whether it was necessary for the Government of India to give reasons for its decision

facts.text: Only one other person applied for prospecting licence which was rejected

anchor.surface_text: Besides the appellant and the respondent No. 3, there was only one other person who applied for a prospecting licence which was rejected off-hand.

facts.text: Appellant annexed copies of documents evidencing precarious financial condition of 3rd respondent in revision

anchor.surface_text: The appellant tried to bring out in his revision applications that the financial condition of the 3rd respondent was extremely precarious as would be evidenced by documents, copies whereof were annexed to his petition.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside orders of Central Government dated June 22, 1966 and directed to decide afresh

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed and the orders of the Central Government passed on 22nd June, 1966 are set aside. The Central Government is directed to decide the review applications afresh in the light of the observations made.

arguments.court_reasoning: r.55 allows new comments/inter-comments constituting record; quasi-judicial requires reasons regardless of explicit provision

arguments.claim: No need for reasons when affirming State order; cites minority in MP Industries, CIT v Pilliah, Nandrant where reasons obvious or not required for affirmance

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes: here State reasons scrappy/nebulous; r.55 involves new material; unlike obvious cases; Art.136 requires speaking orders

arguments.claim: Giving reasons obstructs government work, causes delays

anchor.surface_text: It was there argued that if the Central Government had to give reasons when it functioned as a tribunals it would obstruct the work of the Government and lead to unnecessary delays.

arguments.court_reasoning: Reasons only for judicial/quasi-judicial in small matters; promotes self-discipline, minimizes arbitrariness in welfare state

anchor.surface_text: Let us now examine the question as to whether it was incumbent on the Central Government to give any reasons for its decision on review... A reasoned order is a desirable condition of judicial disposal.

holdings.text: in exercising its powers of revision under r. 55 the Central Government discharges functions which are quasi judicial

anchor.surface_text: in exercising its powers of revision under r. 55 the Central Government discharges functions which are quasi judicial see Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India Ors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of r.55 involves consideration of revision application, comments, inter-comments forming record; cites precedents Shivji Nathubhai and M.P. Industries establishing judicial character.

holdings.text: the Union of India was bound to make a speaking order in dismissing a revision and confirming the order of the State of Andhra Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals by special leave, are limited to the question as to whether in dismissing a revision and confirming the order of the State of Andhra Pradesh, the Union of India was bound to make a speaking order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Central Government acts quasi-judicially under r.55; decisions subject to Art.136 appeal require reasons to enable effective review; State reasons scrappy, new material considered.

holdings.text: both the High Court and this Court are placed under a great disadvantage if no reasons are given

anchor.surface_text: appellate powers of this Court under Art. 136. It goes without saying that both the High Court and this Court are placed under a great disadvantage if no reasons are given

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supervisory (Art.227) and appellate (Art.136) jurisdictions impaired without reasons; forces de novo examination; promotes transparency in quasi-judicial decisions.

holdings.text: it was incumbent on the Central Government to give any reasons for its decision on review

anchor.surface_text: Let us now examine the question as to whether it was incumbent on the Central Government to give any reasons for its decision on review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial tribunal must disclose mind, ensure consideration, minimize arbitrariness; desirable for judicial disposal, especially appealable orders; quotes MP Industries.

holdings.text: In such circumstances, what is known as a speaking order is called for

anchor.surface_text: In such circumstances, what is known as a speaking order is called for. The order of the Central Government of June 22, 1966 is so worded as to be open to the construction

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even on affirmance, if State reasons scrappy/nebulous or new material (comments) considered, reviewing authority must give own reasons or specify adopted ones.

holdings.text: the appeals are allowed and the orders of the Central Government passed on 22nd June, 1966 are set aside

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are allowed and the orders of the Central Government passed on 22nd June, 1966 are set aside. The Central Government is directed to decide the review applications afresh in the light of the observations made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders non-speaking, fail to disclose reasoning despite quasi-judicial nature and r.55 procedure; direct fresh decision after providing reasons.

holdings.text: We are not called upon in this case to go into the merits of the case but only to examine the question as to whether it was necessary for the Government of India to give reasons for its decision

anchor.surface_text: We are not called upon in this case to go into the merits of the case but only to examine the question as to whether it was necessary for the Government of India to give reasons for its decision

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scope of appeals limited to speaking order requirement; merits of mining lease grant not examined.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed this Court in Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India  supra  rules that the Central Government exercising its power

precedents.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government exercising power of review under r. 54 of Mineral Concession Rules 1949 acting judicially as tribunal

precedents.citation: Harinagar Sugar Mills v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1

anchor.surface_text: Now we propose to examine some decisions of this Court where the question as to whether the reviewing authority should give reasons for its decisions was gone into. In Harinagar Sugar Mills v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala 1

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills v Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Central Government exercising appellate powers under Companies Act acts judicially and must give reasons
precedents.cited_holding: If the Central Government acts as a tribunal exercising judicial powers... we fail to see how the power of this Court can be effectively exercised if reasons are not given

anchor.surface_text: In Sardar Govindrao v. State 1  the appellants who to be descendants of former ruling chiefs in same districts of Madhya Pradesh applied under the Central Provinces

precedents.cited_proposition: Government must act in quasi-judicial manner and give reasons for rejection
precedents.cited_holding: The appellants were also entitled to know the reason why their claim... was rejected by Government

anchor.surface_text: In M. P. Industries v. Union 1  the order of the Central Government rejecting the revision application under r. 55 of the Mineral Concession Rules was couched

precedents.case_name: M P Industries v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Need for speaking orders by tribunals

anchor.surface_text: They distinguished the case of Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. 1  on the ground that the Central Government had reversed the decision appealed without giving any reasons

precedents.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd v Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinguished because reversal without reasons differs from affirmance

precedents.citation: Nandrant Hunatram, Calcutta v. Union of India 2

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to a judgment of this Court in Nandrant Hunatram, Calcutta v. Union of India 2 . There, one of the points made by the appellant

precedents.case_name: Nandrant Hunatram v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: No need for reasons where reasons are obvious from facts
precedents.cited_holding: the reasons for the action of the State were so obvious that it was not necessary... to repeat them

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. K. V. pilliah 2

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was also drawn to another judgment of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. K. V. pilliah 2 . One of the questions in that case

precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunal need not repeat reasons if agreeing with lower authority
precedents.cited_holding: in failing to record reasons, when the Appellate Tribunal fully agrees with the view expressed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner... it does not act illegally

precedents.citation: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal, Ex parte Shaw 1

anchor.surface_text: It may be of interest to note that in Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal, Ex parte Shaw 1  an application was made in the Kings Bench Division

precedents.case_name: Rex v Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal ex parte Shaw
precedents.cited_proposition: Benefit of speaking orders for judicial review
precedents.cited_holding: if, in making their orders, they make their orders speaking orders, so that this court can then consider them

anchor.surface_text: Thus in Vedachala Mudaliar v. -State of Madras 3  where the State Government of Madras set aside the order of the Central Road Traffic Board without giving any reasons

precedents.case_name: Vedachala Mudaliar v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Tribunals should give reasons when setting aside orders
precedents.cited_holding: they should be expected to give reasons when they set aside an order of an inferior tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Refrence may also be made to Ramayya v. State of Andhra 2 and Annamalai v. State of Madras 3 .
